instrument.description: Brand and model of the ITC instrument used. Be concise and avoid including extra information such as manufacturer location.

sensor_type.description: Type of sensor used in the BLI experiment. Common types include "Streptavidin-coated", "Protein A-coated", "Ni-NTA-coated", etc. Be sure to note the exact type if mentioned, as it can affect binding.

temperature.description: Temperature at which the ITC experiment was conducted, without unit because it is always in Celsius. Sometimes it is written as "room temperature" or "RT", in which case you can assume it is 25.

binding_model.description: The binding model used to fit the ITC data. Common models include "one-site", "two-sites", "sequential-binding", etc. One-site is the most common model, which has other names like single-site or independent sites, but you should note them all as one-site. If stoichiometry is mentioned (e.g., 1:1, 2:1), also include it.

buffer.description: Composition of the buffer used for loading the ligand onto the sensor. Always put concentration before the chemical (for example "10 mM NaCl" instead of "NaCl 10 mM"). Remove pH information from the "buffer" key and add it to the "pH" key instead. Make sure you account for DMSO or other cosolvents if present as they are sometimes not reported as part of the buffer. Separate multiple components with commas only.

pH.description: pH of the buffer used for loading the ligand onto the sensor.

ligand_concentration.description: Concentration of the ligand for loading. Just extract the information without including any other information. If there are multiple values for a key (for example, because there are multiple compounds with different conditions), list all of them and mark which value is for which (for example "310 μM (radicicol); 300 μM (geldanamycin)" and "20 mM Tris-HCl, 1 mM EDTA (protein), 1% DMSO (ligand)"). If there is only one value, however, there is no need to mark the compound associated with that value. If the concentration is given as a range, keep it as a range in this format: "low-high  unit". Sometimes there may be multiple descriptions of concentrations (usually a more general one and a more specific one); you should use the most specific one.

loading_time.description: Time duration for loading the ligand onto the sensor. This is the amount of time the sensor tip is dipped into the ligand solution. Typically ranges from a few minutes to tens of minutes.

immobilization_level.description: The level of ligand immobilized on the sensor, usually reported in response units (RU).

buffer.description: Composition of the buffer used for washing the sensor tip after loading the ligand onto the sensor. Always put concentration before the chemical (for example "10 mM NaCl" instead of "NaCl 10 mM"). Remove pH information from the "buffer" key and add it to the "pH" key instead. Make sure you account for DMSO or other cosolvents if present as they are sometimes not reported as part of the buffer. Separate multiple components with commas only.

wash_time.description: Time duration for washing the sensor tip after loading the ligand onto the sensor. This is the amount of time the sensor tip is dipped into the wash buffer.

buffer.description: Composition of the buffer used for measuring binding affinity. Always put concentration before the chemical (for example "10 mM NaCl" instead of "NaCl 10 mM"). Remove pH information from the "buffer" key and add it to the "pH" key instead. Make sure you account for DMSO or other cosolvents if present as they are sometimes not reported as part of the buffer. Separate multiple components with commas only.

pH.description: pH of the buffer used for measuring binding affinity.

compound_concentration.description: Concentration of the ligand in the ITC experiment. Just extract the information without including any other information. If there are multiple values for a key (for example, because there are multiple compounds with different conditions), list all of them and mark which value is for which (for example "310 μM (radicicol); 300 μM (geldanamycin)"). If there is only one value, however, there is no need to mark the compound associated with that value. If the concentration is given as a range, keep it as a range in this format: "low-high unit". Sometimes there may be multiple descriptions of concentrations (usually a more general one and a more specific one); you should use the most specific one. If a series of dilutions is used, just extract the concentration of the highest one or the concentration of the stock solution used.

association_time.description: Time duration for the association phase in the BLI experiment. This is the amount of time the sensor tip is dipped into the compound solution.

dissociation_time.description: Time duration for the dissociation phase in the BLI experiment. This is the amount of time the sensor tip is dipped into the buffer after the association phase.

stirring_speed.description: Stirring speed during the ITC experiment.

control.description: Sometimes, a reference experiment (usually called "reference", "control", or "double reference") is run without the ligand, without the compound, using a different buffer system, or using an unreactive pair of ligand-compound. Note that this is not the same as the reference cell in the instrument, but rather a complete, independent measurement for control purpose. You should briefly describe the reference experiment in the "control" key if such an experiment is available, focusing on how the reference experiment is different from the actual measurement. If conditions from the actual measurement are used as baseline (as opposed to a full control experiment), leave this key as null.
examples: biosensor without ligand was titrated with analyte
